node.title: 101 of the Best Songs About California
node.alt: Katy Perry and Snoop Dogg performed “California Gurls” at the 2010 MTV Movie Awards in Los Angeles.
node.description: An unscientific guide to the tracks that evoke the Golden State.
node.content: ["With its dreamy landscapes and near year-round sunshine, California is the kind of place you could write songs about \u2014 and so many people have.", "Today we\u2019re unveiling our (highly unscientific) list of the 101 best songs about the Golden State. This is a playlist that my colleague Jill Cowan created in 2019 and that I\u2019ve recently begun adding to based on your suggestions.", "The music showcased in the current iteration stretches across decades, genres and geographies. On the list are the Beach Boys\u2019 \u201cGood Vibrations\u201d from 1966, LL Cool J\u2019s \u201cGoin Back to Cali\u201d and Haim\u2019s 2020 bop \u201cLos Angeles.\u201d", "As with any playlist, the California Soundtrack is a work in progress that we\u2019ll continue editing and building. You can email your recommendations to me at CAtoday@nytimes.com.", "Below I\u2019m sharing some of the tracks that made the latest cut as well as your arguments for inclusion. I\u2019ll post more of your submissions in the newsletter in the coming weeks.", "You can peruse the full list of 101 California songs here or listen here.", "But before we proceed, my pick: Rilo Kiley\u2019s \u201cLet Me Back In,\u201d from 2013. It\u2019s an ode to Los Angeles that centers what I\u2019ve always loved about this city \u2014 that almost anyone can feel at home here.", "Happy listening.", "\u201cLights\u201d by Journey (1978)", "\u201cJourney is a Bay Area staple. \u2018Lights\u2019 is a love song to the city of San Francisco. The Giants will play \u2018Lights\u2019 in between the seventh and eighth innings (if the Giants are winning) and the whole ballpark sings and sways to the music. It is wonderful!\u201d \u2014 Robin Blair, Palo Alto", "\u201cCalifornia Gurls\u201d by Katy Perry and Snoop Dogg (2010)", "\u201cI\u2019m 64 years young, born and raised in Southern California, and if there\u2019s another song that so aptly describes life during my younger years, I don\u2019t know what it is. I\u2019ve retired to Arizona but Southern California will always be home!!\u201d \u2014 Cheryl Brown, Surprise, Ariz.", "\u201cWhere the Streets Have No Name\u201d by U2 (1987)", "\u201cThis is a song that anyone who has been out to the Mojave and has experienced the heaviness of the universe and fragility of their mortality would agree is about the spiritual growth that occurs there. Not to mention the album is called \u2018Joshua Tree.\u2019\u201d \u2014 Ana Mac\u00edas-Serpa, Arundel, Maine", "\u201cPacheco / The Red Tailed Hawk\u201d by Kate Wolf (1983)", "\u201cWhen we are driving home, heading north on Route 5 on our way to Santa Cruz, the song describes our ride, and the climb up over Pacheco Pass, perfectly. We always play it as we head up the pass.\u201d \u2014 Joyce Smith, Santa Cruz", "\u201cHow Big, How Blue, How Beautiful\u201d by Florence and the Machine (2015)", "\u201cWhen I saw her in concert, she said she was inspired to write that song as she was coming in to land at LAX.", "On a personal note, my girlfriend and I were listening to this album on a trip along Highway 1 in Marin County in 2015 when we came around a tight turn to a breathtaking view of the ocean just as that song started to play. It was an ethereal, perfect moment and I would urge anyone on a Highway 1 adventure to add it to their playlist.\u201d \u2014 Holly Ober, Riverside", "\u201cVentura Highway\u201d by America (1972)", "\u201cWhenever driving from my place in San Francisco to visit my daughter in Southern California, I remember to put on America\u2019s 1972 release of \u2018Ventura Highway\u2019 as the ocean comes into view on the right of Highway 101 and the blue Pacific Ocean seemingly goes on forever until it melds into an equally blue sky. It\u2019s mesmerizing and so California.\u201d \u2014 Kathleen Richter, San Francisco", "For $1.9 million in California.", "Honey-roasted brussels sprouts with harissa.", "Today\u2019s travel tip comes from Michael Hamilton, who recommends La Cumbre Peak, the tallest mountain overlooking Santa Barbara:", "Tell us about your favorite places to visit in California. Email your suggestions to CAtoday@nytimes.com. We\u2019ll be sharing more in upcoming editions of the newsletter.", "With Valentine\u2019s Day coming up, we\u2019re asking about love: not who you love, but what you love about your corner of California.", "Email us a love letter to your California city, neighborhood or region \u2014 or to the Golden State as a whole \u2014 and we may share it in an upcoming newsletter. You can reach the team at CAtoday@nytimes.com.", "Today is the Lunar New Year, which means the moon is entering a new phase, the Year of the Tiger is beginning and many Asian families will be celebrating with cut fruit.", "Eating or giving fruit is a beloved Lunar New Year tradition, with different fruits carrying different meanings.", "Apples are supposed to bring peace, and so are pomelos. Golden-hued fruits like oranges, tangerines and kumquats are believed to bring wealth to those who eat them, as their gold colors are reminiscent of money.", "Thanks for reading. I\u2019ll be back tomorrow. \u2014 Soumya", "P.S. Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Coin toss call (5 letters).", "Mariel Wamsley and Jonah Candelario contributed to California Today.
